entries.text: I'm a Perl programmer and open-source developer who also specialises in Perl recruitment in Europe. If you want to know if you're being paid enough, want some help with your CV, or just want to talk to a recruiter who knows the difference between 'local' and 'my', say hello at: http://perl.careers/.
entries.title: Perl Recruitment by a CPAN contributor

entries.text: Have you wondered how do those Perl Maven Pro screencasts look like, but wasn't sure about the money part? Now you can try it for free for one month. But don't wait too much, because this offer is only valid till the end of the week.
entries.title: One month free Perl Maven Pro subscription

entries.text: Jeffrey Thalhammer (THALJEF) announced that perlcritic.com (a web interface to his popular Perl::Critic module) has been moved to new hardware and completely rewritten (source in github).

entries.title: Get CPANstats from MetaCPAN using cron

chapters.title: Perl Maven Pro

entries.text: Vytas Dauksa (VYTAS) describes how he thinks Perl could be made more palatable for use in education. It can be summarised as 'enable all the Modern Perl stuff, break backwards compatibility to drop some of the legacy features, and bundle the best of CPAN'.
entries.title: RFC Perl for education

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Gabor Szabo (SZABGAB) has started curating a list of Perl-based web sites for which the source is available.
entries.title: Web sites with source code for hacking

entries.author: sinan_unur
entries.text: Sinan Unur (NANIS) decided to try and compile Rakudo Perl with Visual Studio 2013, which Microsoft made freely available.
entries.title: Building Perl 6 with Visual Studio 2013

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.text: David Farrell (SILLYMOOS) suggests that a good way to get started with Perl 6 is by writing one-liners.
entries.title: Get started with Perl 6 one liners

entries.text: Sinan Unur (NANIS) demonstrates why we all need to know how to use quotemeta.
entries.title: TDD is all well and good, but who's testing the tests?

entries.text: Barbie (BARBIE) posted his monthly round-up of news related to CPAN Testers.
entries.title: CPAN Testers Summary - October 2014

entries.author: dan_wright
entries.text: Dan Wright describes the budgeting process of The Perl Foundation.
entries.title: Inside look at TPF's budget process

entries.text: Peter Baranyi has released the source for mailnesia, a disposable email service.
entries.title: Mailnesia goes open source

entries.author: ricardo_signes
entries.text: Rik Signes (RJBS) has released a trial version of Email::MIME::Kit v3, which sorts out encodings, but might temporarily make your life worse, if you were (possibly unknowingly) relying on the previous brokenness.
entries.title: Email::MIME::Kit v3 will fix-and-or-break your code

entries.author: jt_smith
entries.text: JT Smith (RIZEN) has released Imager::Draw::Hexagon. Given the name, you might be surprised to discover that it's for drawing hexagons using Imager.
entries.title: Imager::Draw::Hexagon - Draw hexes easily using Imager

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: Neil Bowers (NEILB) created a simple interface to todoist.com, an online todolist service. He also finds it weird writing about himself in the third person.
entries.title: todoist - a script interface to todoist.com

entries.author: taiki_kawakami
entries.text: Taiki Kawakami (MOZNION) has released the first non-developer version of Perl::Lint, which was funded by a previous grant.
entries.title: Perl::Lint released
